bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Interpretation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise indicated, words and expressions not defined in this regulation have the meaning given to them in section 1 of the Forest Planning and Practices Regulation.
In the Act, except section 109, and in this regulation, contractor does not include a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to whom an obligation has been transferred under section 29.1 of the Act, or
who is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: authorized under section 51 (2) of the Act to maintain a range development, and
not the holder of an agreement under the Range Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prescribed category of persons

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of sections 74 (1) (b) and 77 (1) of the Act, the following are prescribed categories of persons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: persons to whom obligations have been transferred under section 29.1 of the Act;
persons who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are authorized under section 51 (2) of the Act to maintain range developments, and
are not the holders of agreements under the Range Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: persons who, after the expiry, surrender, suspension or cancellation of agreements under the Forest Act, remain liable under sectionÂ 79 of the Forest Act to perform obligations referred to in paragraph (c) of that section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 107 (1) of the Act, the requirements that a person must meet in order to submit a written declaration under that section are that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is one to whom an obligation has been transferred under section 29.1 of the Act,
the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is authorized under section 51 (2) of the Act to maintain a range development, and
is not the holder of an agreement under the Range Act, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is the timber sales manager.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Stop work orders not stayed
bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 66 of the Act is a prescribed section for the purposes of section 78 (3) of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rescinding stop work orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The circumstances in which, under section 66 (6) of the Act, an official or the minister may rescind an order made against the holder of an agreement or another person under section 66 (1) of the Act are that the order is no longer required or is no longer appropriate.

Even if an order referred to in subsection (1) against the holder of an agreement is rescinded, the rescinded order is part of the holder's performance record for the purposes of section 85 of the Act and is to be noted in that record, together with the particulars of the rescission.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dealing with seized timber, seed, hay and botanical forest products
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 67 (3) (a) of the Act, before dealing with seized timber, seed, hay or botanical forest products referred to in that section, the minister must give an opportunity to be heard to the person from whom the timber, seed, hay or botanical forest products were seized.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Intervention orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 77 (1) and (2) and section 77.1 of the Act, an order given by the minister to a person described under either section must specify

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the measures or actions that must be taken,
the date by which the measures or actions must be taken,
the grounds for requiring the measures or actions to be taken,
notice of the person's right under

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 80 of the Act to a review, or
section 82 of the Act to an appeal,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an address to which a request for a review may be delivered, and
whether the holder may recover all or part of the amount reasonably incurred in taking the specified measures or actions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may take action under section 77 (1) of the Act if an act or omission of the person who is the subject of the order will likely result in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a substantial non-conformance with the stocking requirements described in section 44 (1) (b) or 45 (2) of the Forest Planning and Practices Regulation,
a significant delay in meeting the stocking requirements by the dates described in section 44 (1) (b) or 45 (2) of the Forest Planning and Practices Regulation, or
a fundamental and adverse alteration of an ecosystem.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before taking an action under section 77 (1) or 77.1 (1) of the Act in respect of a person, the minister must give the person an opportunity to be heard.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Payment of expenses related to orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The expenses of the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act in carrying out a measure other than timber harvesting, as required by order under sectionÂ 26 or 27 of the Forest and Range Practices Act, are to be paid by the government to the extent that the minister is satisfied that the expenses were reasonably incurred.

The expenses of the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act, in carrying out a measure as required by order under sectionÂ 77.1 of the Forest and Range Practices Act, that are greater than the expenses the holder would have incurred if the order had not been made are to be paid by the government to the extent that the minister is satisfied that the expenses were reasonably incurred.

The condition on which a person who has taken measures under section 77 (1) or (2) of the Act may recover direct costs referred to in section 77 (3) of the Act is that those costs were in fact reasonably incurred.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Penalties â unauthorized forest or range activities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The maximum amount that the minister may levy against a person under section 71 (2) of the Forest and Range Practices Act for a contravention of section 50 (2) of that Act is an amount equal to the product of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area, expressed in hectares, that contained the hay that was the subject of the contravention, and
$1 000 per ha.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The maximum amount that the minister may levy against a person under section 71 (2) of the Forest and Range Practices Act for a contravention of section 52 (1) or (3) of that Act is the greatest of the following amounts:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an amount equal to the product of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the volume, expressed in cubic metres, of the Crown timber that was the subject of the contravention, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an amount equal to the product of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the area, expressed in hectares, that contained the timber that was the subject of the contravention, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an amount equal to the sum of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the stumpage and bonus bid that in the opinion of the minister would have been payable if the volume of timber that was the subject of the contravention had been sold under a BC timber sales agreement at the time of the contravention,
twice the market value of logs and special forest products that in the opinion of the minister were, or could have been, produced from the timber that was the subject of the contravention,
the costs that have been or will be incurred by the government in re-establishing a free growing stand on the area, and
the costs that were incurred by the government for silviculture treatments to the area that were rendered ineffective because of the contravention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For a contravention of section 52 of the Forest and Range Practices Act, the minister, in a penalty levied under section 71 (2) of that Act, may not include any amount for the value of the timber, if any, that is recoverable under section 103 of the Forest Act.
